captions.text:
When someone accuses a police officer of misconduct,
it's often a he said-she said situation. But

video is completely changing that. Ever since
a bystander recorded Rodney King being beaten

by Los Angeles police in 1991, the power has
been in the hands of witnesses, especially

now that so many people have camera phones.
But it's up to chance whether a bystander

captures an interaction on video or not. Most
police departments now have in-vehicle dashboard

cameras, but they vary in how they're used.
Now, there's a rapid rise in the number of

police departments who are testing body cameras,
so that all interactions can be recorded,

not just the ones that take place right in
front of a police car. In some cases, video

evidence can be the key that demonstrates
that a police officer really did commit a
crime. "Can I see your license please?"

"Get
out of the car! Get out of the car!" [shots fired].

"Get on the ground! Get on the ground!"
"I just got my license. You said get my license!"

When police officers aren't conviced, or even
charged, after an episode of misconduct, video

can show how wide the gulf is between what
many people feel is acceptable and what cops are

allowed to do, such as the killiing of John
Crawford for carrying a toy rifle in 
a Walmart.
[shots fired]
But bodycams and dashcams are also helpful to police. In fact, video evidence exonerates cops more often

than it convicts them. And some cities have
found that just using cameras puts everyone

on their best behavior. One town in California
found that use-of-force incidents dropped

60% after police started using body cameras.
The next big question is control of video

footage: When cameras get activated, how footage
gets stored, and who's allowed to edit a video

before it gets released. In several cases,
body cameras or dashcams have "malfunctioned"

or gone dark at critical moments, raising
concerns that the footage is being manipulated.

Imagine how that might have affected something
like a recent New Jersey case, where the jury
might have heard this:
Instead of seeing this:

title: Why recording the police is so important

comments.author: Vesuvius Lee

comments.text:
Cops should be recording at all times and not be allowed to go out with 
"defective equipment". There's too much at stake. These people have too 
much power to go around doing whatever they want. Accountability is key.

Don't assume that just because someone is a cop that they are good people. 
Honestly, if you are a bad person and want to hurt as many people as you 
can and get away with it, the easiest way is to be a cop.

Also, internal affairs should be a completely independent organization. 
They should have absolutely no reason to be corrupted by police. The way 
it's set up right now IA are just the people that help evil cops get away 
with their crimes.﻿

keep the video taking discreet if you can, god knows it's not always a good 
idea to let officer friendly have a reason to be mad at you.

comments.text:
+inacarjam Nice comment :) i live in a small town i Norway, i smoke pot 
instead of drinking alcohol, it must be noted that i do in fact have a job 
and a perfectly normal life aside from smoking pot, for those who think all 
people who smoke pot is not doing anything and just sit home and get stoned 
all day. We have police officers who are friends and hang out with 
convicted pedophiles, police officers who are not fully educated. i was 
told this the first encounter i had with the police: We can be real dicks 
if we want to, and take your drivers license away if you don't start 
helping us, and by helping us they mean rat out all the people i know who 
smoke weed. I have never been stopped due to high speed i don't even have 
one parking ticket under my belt, now i am left in a small town with little 
to no jobs available and no car to get to work because i chose to not rat 
out my friends and i only have a contract until this summer is over its 
gonna get hard to get work in the future but i refuse to have a person in a 
uniform thinking he can control my life, give me the fine and leave me 
alone .... in Norway police officers are not allowed to carry guns, but il 
tell you this... if they cant shot you and kill you or beat you up, just 
because they don't like you, they WILL make your life as shitty as they can 
and take away as much as they can until you are left with nothing... To 
have so much responsibility as a police officer does is a hard task and i 
know i could not do this myself... its to easy to become a cop... If all 
cops had to wear a personal video camera and the video they captured was 
the evidence and not just what the police said, we would not have this 
problem with the "he said, she said bull****" and a very important note: 
Ofc not all cops/humans are bad... But its obvious that we have no idea who 
the good guys are and who the bad guys are... we need a new better system 
cus this shit got out of hand years ago... people who had a hard time in 
school or otherwise had a hard time growing up has a harder time 
controlling them self when they are presented with so much potential power 
to control others. i sucks to be exiled and forced to just sit inside and 
rot because someone with power does not like you because of what you do in 
your own home. although i would love to be as productive as society wants 
me to be im afraid that i wont be able to do so in the future... and its 
not because i choose to sit inside and not do anything, its because of 
corrupted police officers who love the feeling of being in control.....

comments.author: 11YinYang11JenGer77

comments.text:
It seems to me that many ppl are forgetting that the police in the US are 
doing their job in a country where a large percentage of the population are 
rightly or wrongly, legally or illegally better armed than they are (it 
also seems a lot of folks over there go about their daily business with big 
heavy chips on their shoulders and nasty tempers/undue aggression) It's not 
hard to imagine anyone in law enforcement in the US starting their career 
with all the best intentions to serve honourably but over time becoming 
jaded, cynical and yeah, even corrupt and thuggish. After all, in many 
areas cops know that if they aren't careful they could very easily get dead 
and so learn to be a thug first and ask questions later (this has some 
disturbing parallels with the My Lai incident in the Vietnam war). 
Remember, they may have dependents who will be a lot worse off if they get 
killed in the line of duty and nobody wants to get killed doing their job 
for a wage that, lets be honest here, is barely worth that kind of risk no 
matter how much of an idealist one may be. I'm not defending bad police and 
bad policing practices but they can't all be complete 'psychos' and the 
ones that are probably have a reason (most likely to do with the extreme 
pressure of the job and having to daily see the worst of human nature) 
but nobody is born 'bad'. One thing I would like to know is what the 
procedure is in the US when a cop shoots and kills or wounds a civvy. Here 
in the UK the officer in question is disarmed and arrested by their partner 
or another colleague and is suspended pending a full investigation and is 
pretty much treated as guilty of murder/assault until cleared of any 
wrongdoing. I've had a few run ins with the law myself here in the UK and 
every time I've been decently treated with respect but then I've given 
respect so I earned it even when the cops in question thought I'd beat my 
now ex wife (which I didn't btw, we argued a lot and she tried to beat me 
and wind me up so I would snap and I wouldn't take the bait. Turns out she 
was bipolar or something) The only time a cop has ever yelled at me was 
when our old neighbour had a breakdown and was wandering the street with a 
shotgun and I, being oblivious to all this thanks to my MP3 player, walked 
out of the driveway and into a stand off between a firearms team and the 
neighbour who ended up shooting himself in the head (he actually survived 
the attempt to blow his own head off and I got over the shock of being 
charged by a load of bulky guys with big guns. Kinda funny when I think of 
it) Lastly, you Americans will live in an often violent society with guns 
everywhere but you won't do anything meaningful about it so really, don't 
complain too much ok, it makes you look whiny and dumb.﻿

comments.author: Viper Hydar

comments.text:
The Crawford Walmart shooting is so bad on both sides.
Anybody Carrying a pellet gun wandering around like that is going to draw 
attention, that was very poor judgement.
Im NOT saying he should of been shot for it. But you can not tell if its 
rifle or pellet gun. With all the nut jobs shooting up people and schools 
you can understand the concern for a 911 call. If it was his and he was 
returning it put it in a bag or box. Walk down the street with a BB gun and 
see what happens.  This was a bad move on his part. I dont understand what 
made the cops shoot so fast though. The gun wasnt raised he was on a phone 
and he was surrounded. Im sure they were concerned of a shoot out in a 
store but still your trained to be accurate so getting him down should be 
easy.
As I said this was just meant to end bad for everybody... Horrible horrible 
thing.﻿
comments.author: Gerard Man

comments.text:
I hope people remember there are thousands and thousands of cops. So many 
have their good name smeared because of the actions of the dirty ones. So 
its hard to know who to trust. A cop who is paid by the public to protect 
the public that are dirty should be sentenced times two. What would a 
normal black guy get and multiply it by two for betraying the public trust 
and the destruction of cops reputation. Like kids the more you can get away 
with something the more and worse you will do it. I tend to support the 
police. Some people who get their asses kicked are scum bags and they have 
tons of interaction with the police wasting all their time and our 
resources. I just dont care about them. But then how care you draw the 
line. I dont know. I hope all dangerous and violent criminals meet a dirty 
cop. But then we are back to square one again. So maybe do the right thing 
as a cop and fix the courts and lock the right people up. Prisons don have 
to have so many amenities, cut the cost and lock up the violent much 
longer.﻿
comments.author: Gerard Man
